pr_title: Add default global rules supplied via env vars

timeline.bodyText: If the same rule is configured in both places, won't it show up twice in the list?
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText:
getDefaultGlobalRules() takes a list of RuleType enums that will be filtered out of the returned list. So this concatenation of the 2 lists will only include the global rules that are in storage plus any default global rules that aren't in the list from storage.
I have renamed getDefaultGlobalRules() to getFilteredDefaultGlobalRules() in the latest commit to hopefully make it clearer that it's (potentially) a sub-list that is returned.
replies.author: ajborley

replies.bodyText: Ah yes - that is the part I missed.  I didn't notice that it was passing in the rules.
replies.author: EricWittmann

timeline.bodyText: But if the global rule does exist then the API responds with a 20x (success) response without having done anything.  Do we need a new response for that?  Some sort of HTTP conflict response?
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText: Good point - I have updated this to throw a new exception type (DefaultRuleDeletionException) and return a 409 Conflict response.
replies.author: ajborley

timeline.bodyText: I think this should remain - if there are no rules to apply we want to skip the UPDATE section below.
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText: Good spot, have put it back!
replies.author: ajborley

timeline.bodyText: This could be me misunderstanding how concat() works, but won't this be a problem if the same rule exists in both?  We don't want to run the rules twice.  But maybe concat de-dupes the items in the stream?
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText: This is down to my badly-named method again. Hopefully it's clearer now - in this case defaultGlobalRules only contains configured rules that are not found in the rules from storage.
replies.author: ajborley

timeline.bodyText: Do we want the default rules to take precedent over configured rules?  Probably not?
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText: As defaultGlobalRules only contains rules that are not found in the rules from storage, then we know to retrieve the rule configuration from the default global rules here. Otherwise the rule must be from storage, so we get the configuration from storage.
replies.author: ajborley

timeline.bodyText: While you're in here, can you rename this method to applyRules since I believe it applies all rules not just one?  IMO this was not properly named originally.
timeline.author: EricWittmann

timeline.message:
Address review comments

 - Refactor code in RulesServiceImpl
 - Rename RulesProperties.getFilteredDefaultGlobalRules() method for
clarity.
 - Add DefaultRuleDeletionException, thrown when attempting to delete a
default global rule.
 - Rename version-specific RulesService.applyRule to applyRules.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>

Add tests for default global rules

 - This commit uses a new implementation of the QuarkusTestProfile
interface to set a default global rule via configuration overrides. This
allows the default global rule functionality to be tested in the new
test class.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText: I think this should be wrapped in a check for useGlobalRules.  Basically, if there are rules defined at the artifact level, we always use those - we never merge the global rules (configured or default) with the artifact rules.
timeline.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText: The logic is that configured artifact rules always override globals... the idea was that the user needs a way to say "enable validation but not compatibility" even when the compatibility rule has been configured globally.  However, now that I write this out, there is no way for the user to say "disable all rules" at the artifact level, because that would look the same as "no artifact rule configuration exists".  :( :(
replies.author: EricWittmann

replies.bodyText:
The Validity rule can be given a NONE value - if we add a NONE for the Compatibility rule (and handle it in the checking code) then a user could override any global rules for a specific artifact. Does that work?
Thanks for clarifying the precedence of rules - I have refactored that code to hopefully clarify things.
Still working on why the tests are failing..
replies.author: ajborley

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think using the NONE configuration option is the only solution I can think of as well.  I'll open a ticket to add that option to the compat rule.
replies.author: EricWittmann

timeline.message:
Refactor to ensure separation of artifact and global rules

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>

Add default global rules supplied via env vars

 - This commit adds the ability to supply default global rules on
registry start-up via environment variables. In the server config these
are defined as:
    - `%{profile}.registry.rules.global.compatibility`
    - `%{profile}.registry.rules.global.validity`
 and are set with the configuration value for each rule (e.g. `FULL` or
`BACKWARDS`).

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>

Address review comments

 - Refactor code in RulesServiceImpl
 - Rename RulesProperties.getFilteredDefaultGlobalRules() method for
clarity.
 - Add DefaultRuleDeletionException, thrown when attempting to delete a
default global rule.
 - Rename version-specific RulesService.applyRule to applyRules.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>

Add tests for default global rules

 - This commit uses a new implementation of the QuarkusTestProfile
interface to set a default global rule via configuration overrides. This
allows the default global rule functionality to be tested in the new
test class.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Borley <borley@uk.ibm.com>
